'''Adolf Dygasiński''' (March 7, 1839, [[Niegosławice, Pińczów County|Niegosławice]]–June 3, 1902, [[Grodzisk Mazowiecki]]) was a [[Poland|Polish]] novelist, publicist and educator. In [[Polish literature]], he was one of the leading representatives of [[Naturalism (literature)|Naturalism]]. ==Life== During his literary career, Dygasiński wrote forty-two short stories and novels. Since 1884 his works were being published in book-form and enjoyed considerable success. They were translated into Russian and German. In 1891, Dygasiński went on a trip to Brazil on a trail of Polish emigrants from [[Partitioned Poland]]. He produced a series of letters describing the tragic fate of Polish emigrees in South America. In the following years Dygasiński maintained a position of a tutor and coach for numerous wealthy landowning families. Late in life he settled in [[Warsaw]], where he died on June 6, 1902, and was buried at the local [[Powązkowski Cemetery]].
==Works== In his work Dygasiński often focused on topics of rural life and residents of small towns, highlighting the common fate of both, human and animal communities. Some of his most important work include:
*Wilk, psy i ludzie (Wolf, dogs and humans; 1883) *Ogólne zasady pedagogiki dotyczące wykształcenia umysłu, uczuć, moralności i religijności (General principles of teaching in the education of mind, emotions, morality, and religion; 1883) *Na pańskim dworze (1884) At the court of the Lord (1884) *Głód i miłość (Hunger and Love; 1885) *Na warszawskim bruku (On the streets of Warsaw, 1886) *Nowe tajemnice Warszawy (New secrets of Warsaw; Vol. 1-2, 1887) *Właściciele (Owners; 1888) *Beldonek (Beldonek; 1888) *Jak się uczyć i jak uczyć innych (How to learn and how to teach others; 1889) *Pan Jędrzej Piszczalski (Mr. Jędrzej Piszczalski; 1890) *Na złamanie karku (At breakneck speed; 1893) *Gorzałka (Booze; 1894) *Żywot Beldonka (Beldonek's Life; 1898) *As (As; 1896) *Zając (Hare; 1900) *Listy z Brazylii (Letters from Brazil; 1900) *Margiela i Margielka (Margiela and Margielka; 1901) *Gody życia (Mating Life; 1902)
==See also== * [[History of philosophy in Poland#Positivism|History of philosophy in Poland]] * [[List of Poles#Philosophy|List of Poles]]
==External links== *[http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9031668 Biography]

The '''disposable soma theory of aging''' states that organisms age due to an evolutionary trade-off between growth, reproduction, and [[DNA repair|DNA repair maintenance]].<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite journal |authors=Kirkwood, T. | year = 1977 | title = Evolution of ageing | journal = Nature | volume = 270 | issue = | pages = 301–304 | doi=10.1038/270301a0| bibcode = 1977Natur.270..301K }}</ref> Formulated by [[Thomas Kirkwood]], the disposable soma theory explains that an organism only has a limited amount of resources or "soma" that it can allocate to its various [[cellular processes]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Gavrilov LA, Gavrilova NS | year = 2002 | title = Evolutionary theories of aging and longevity | journal = ScientificWorldJournal | volume = 7 | issue =2 | pages = 339–356 | doi=10.1100/tsw.2002.96}}</ref> Therefore, a greater investment in growth and reproduction would result in reduced investment in DNA repair maintenance, leading to increased [[Cell damage|cellular damage]], [[telomere#shortening|shortened telomeres]], accumulation of [[mutation#harmful mutations|mutations]], compromised [[stem cells]], and ultimately, [[senescence]]. Although many models, both animal and human, have appeared to support this theory, parts of it are still controversial. Specifically, while the [[evolutionary trade-off]] between [[Mechanistic target of rapamycin#Aging|growth and aging]] has been well established, the relationship between reproduction and aging is still without [[scientific consensus]], and the cellular mechanisms largely undiscovered.<ref name="ReferenceC">{{cite journal |authors=Blagosklonny, MV | year = 2010| title = Why the disposable soma theory cannot explain why women live longer and why we age | journal = Aging | volume = 2 | issue = 12 | pages = 884–887 | doi=10.18632/aging.100253}}</ref>
== Background and history ==
British biologist Thomas Kirkwood first proposed the disposable soma theory of aging in a 1977 [[Nature (journal)|''Nature'']] review article.<ref name="ReferenceA" /> The theory was inspired by [[Leslie Orgel|Leslie Orgel's]] [[Error catastrophe|Error Catastrophe Theory of Aging]], which was published fourteen years earlier, in 1963. Orgel believed that the process of aging arose due to mutations acquired during the replication process, and Kirkwood developed the disposable soma theory in order to mediate Orgel's work with [[evolutionary genetics]].<ref name="ReferenceA" />
==Principles== The disposable soma theory of aging acts on the premise that there is a tradeoff in [[resource allocation]] between [[Maintenance of an organism|somatic maintenance]] and [[Parental investment|reproductive investment]]. Too low an investment in self-repair would be evolutionarily unsound, as the organism would likely die before reproductive age. However, too high an investment in self-repair would also be [[Fitness (biology)|evolutionarily unsound]] due to the fact that one's [[Survivorship curve|offspring would likely die before reproductive age]]. Therefore, there is a compromise and resources are partitioned accordingly. However, this compromise is thought to damage somatic repair systems, which can lead to [[DNA damage theory of aging|progressive cellular damage and senescence]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Drenos F, Kirkwood, TB | year = 2005| title = Modelling the disposable soma theory of ageing | journal = Mech Ageing Dev. | volume = 126 | issue = 1 | pages = 99–103| doi=10.1016/j.mad.2004.09.026}}</ref> Repair costs can be categorized into three groups: (1) the costs of increased [[Regeneration (biology)#Tissues|durability of nonrenewable parts]]; (2) the costs of maintenance involving [[Autophagy|cell renewal]], and (3) the costs of intracellular maintenance.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Kirkwood, TB, Rose MR | year = 1991| title = Evolution of senescence: late survival sacrificed for reproduction.| journal = Philos Trans R Soc Lond B Biol Sci | volume = 332 | issue = 1262 | pages = 15–24| doi=10.1098/rstb.1991.0028}}</ref> In a nutshell, [[Antagonistic pleiotropy hypothesis|aging and decline is essentially a tradeoff]] for increased reproductive robustness in youth.
== Mechanisms == [[File:IGF-1Pathway.png|thumb|The [[IGF-1|IGF-1 pathway]], which represses [[FOXO]], thus preventing [[gene expression]] of longevity-inducing proteins.]]
=== Growth and somatic maintenance === {{main|Mechanistic target of rapamycin#Aging}} Much research has been done on the antagonistic effects of increased growth on lifespan. Specifically, the hormone [[insulin-like growth factor 1]] (IGF-1), binds to a cell receptor, leading to a [[phosphorylation cascade]]. This cascade results in kinases phosphorylating [[FOX proteins|forkhead transcription factor]] (FOXO), deactivating it. Deactivation of FOXO results in an inability to express genes involved in responding to [[oxidative stress |oxidative stress response]], such as [[antioxidants]], [[Chaperone (protein)|chaperones]], and [[heat-shock proteins]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=O'Neill BT, Lee KY, Klaus K, Softic S; et al. | year = 2016 | title = Insulin and IGF-1 receptors regulate FoxO-mediated signaling in muscle proteostasis | journal = J Clin Invest | volume = 126 | issue = 9 | pages = 3433-3346 | doi=10.1172/JCI86522| pmc = 5004956 }}</ref> Additionally, uptake of IGF-1 stimulates the [[Mechanistic target of rapamycin|mTOR]] pathway, which activates protein synthesis (and therefore growth) through upregulation of the translation-promoting [[P70-S6 Kinase 1|S6K1]], and also inhibits [[autophagy]], a process necessary for recycling of damaged cellular products.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Johnson SC, Rabinovitch PS, Kaeberlein M| year = 2013 | title = mTOR is a key modulator of ageing and age-related disease| journal = Nature | volume = 493 | issue = | pages = 338–345 | doi=10.1038/nature11861| bibcode = 2013Natur.493..338J| pmc = 3687363}}</ref> Decline of autophagy causes [[neurodegeneration]], [[protein aggregation]] and [[premature aging]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Komatsu M, Waguri S, Chiba T, Murata S; et al. | year = 2006 | title = Loss of autophagy in the central nervous system causes neurodegeneration in mice | journal = Nature | volume = 441 | issue = | pages = 880–884 | doi=10.1038/nature04723| bibcode = 2006Natur.441..880K }}</ref> Lastly, studies have also indicated that the mTOR pathway also alters [[immune responses]] and stimulates [[cyclin-dependent kinase]] (CDK) inhibitors such as [[p16]] and [[p21]]. This leads to alteration of the [[stem-cell niche]] and results in [[Stem cell theory of aging|stem cell exhaustion]], another theorized mechanism of aging.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Castilho RM1, Squarize CH, Chodosh LA, Williams BO; et al. | year = 2009| title = mTOR mediates Wnt-induced epidermal stem cell exhaustion and aging.| journal = Cell Stem Cell | volume = 5 | issue = 3 | pages = 279–289. | doi=10.1016/j.stem.2009.06.017}}</ref>
=== Reproduction and somatic maintenance=== The mechanism of why reproduction inhibits lifespan with regards to multicellular organisms is still unclear. Although many models do illustrate an inverse relationship, and the theory makes sense from an evolutionary perspective, [[Cell signaling|the cellular mechanisms]] have yet to be explored. However, with regards to [[cellular replication]], the progressive shortening of telomeres is a mechanism which [[Hayflick limit|limits the amount of generations of a single cell may undergo]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Shay JW, Wright WE | year = 2011 | title = Role of telomeres and telomerase in cancer | journal = Semin Cancer Biol. | volume = 21 | issue = 6 | pages = 349–353 | doi=10.1016/j.semcancer.2011.10.001}}</ref> Furthermore, in unicellular organisms like ''[[Saccharomyces cerevisiae]]'', the formation of [[extrachromosomal rDNA circle]]s (ERCs) in mother cells (but not daughter cells) upon every subsequent division is an identifiable type of DNA damage that is associated with replication. These ERCs accumulate over time and eventually trigger replicative senescence and death of the mother cell.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Kaeberlein M, McVey M, Guarente L | year = 1999 | title = The SIR2/3/4 complex and SIR2 alone promote longevity in Saccharomyces cerevisiae by two different mechanisms| journal = Genes Dev. | volume = 13 | issue = 19| pages = 2570–2580}}</ref>
==Evidence==
===Growth and aging=== There is a large body of evidence indicating the negative effects of growth on longevity across many species. As a general rule, individuals of a smaller size generally live longer than larger individuals of the same species.
==== Animal models ==== In [[Dwarfism|dwarf]] models of [[Mus musculus|mice]], such Snell or Ames mice, mutations have arisen, either rendering them incapable of producing IGF-1 or unable to have adequate receptors for IGF-1 uptake. Furthermore, mice injected with growth hormone have been shown to have progressive weight loss, roughing of the coat, [[Scoliosis|curvature of the spine]], [[Hypertrophy|enlargement of the organs]], kidney lesions and [[Cancer|increased cancer risk]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Bartke A1, Brown-Borg H | year = 2004 | title = Life extension in the dwarf mouse | journal = Curr Top Dev Biol. | volume = 63 | issue = | pages = 189–225| doi=10.1016/j.semcancer.2011.10.001}}</ref> This effect is also seen in different breeds of [[dogs]], where smaller breeds of dogs typically live significantly longer compared to their larger counterparts. Selectively bred for their small size, smaller dog breeds like the [[Chihuahua (dog)|Chihuahua]] (average lifespan of 15–20 years) have the B/B genotype for the IGF-1 [[haplotype]], reducing the amount of IGF-1 produced. Conversely, large dogs like the [[Great Dane]] (average lifespan of 6–8 years) are [[homozygous]] for the IGF-1 I [[allele]], which increases the amount of IGF-1 production.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Sutter NB, Bustamante CD, Chase K, Gray MM | year = 2007| title =A Single IGF1 Allele Is a Major Determinant of Small Size in Dogs| journal = Science | volume = 316 | issue = 5821 | pages = 112–115 | doi=10.1126/science.1137045| bibcode =2007Sci...316..112S}}</ref>
====Human models==== Initially, it was believed that growth hormone actually prolonged lifespan due to a 1990 study that indicated that injection of [[growth hormone]] to men over 60 years of age appeared to reverse various [[biomarkers]] implicated in aging, such as [[Sarcopenia|decreased muscle mass]], bone density, skin thickness, and increased adipose tissue.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Rudman D1, Feller AG, Nagraj HS, Gergans GA; et al. | year = 1990| title =Effects of human growth hormone in men over 60 years old| journal = N Engl J Med | volume = 323 | issue = 1 | pages = 1–6 | doi=10.1056/NEJM199007053230101}}</ref> However, a 1999 study found that administering growth hormone also significantly increased [[mortality rate]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Takala J1, Ruokonen E, Webster NR, Nielsen MS, Zandstra DF, et al. | year = 1999| title = Increased mortality associated with growth hormone treatment in critically ill adults| journal = N Engl J Med | volume = 341 | issue = 11 | pages = 785–792 | doi=10.1056/NEJM199909093411102}}</ref> Recent [[Genome Sequencing|genomic studies]] have confirmed that the genes involved in growth hormone uptake and signaling are largely conserved across a plethora of species, such as yeast, nematodes, fruit flies, mice and humans.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Longo VD, Finch CE.| year = 2003| title =Evolutionary medicine: from dwarf model systems to healthy centenarians?| journal = Science | volume = 299 | issue = 5611 | pages = 1342–1346 | doi=10.1126/science.1077991}}</ref> These studies have also shown that individuals with [[Laron syndrome]], an [[autosomal recessive]] disorder resulting in dwarfism due to defects in growth hormone receptors, have increased lifespan. Additionally, these individuals have much lower [[Incidence (epidemiology)|incidences]] of age-related diseases such as [[type 2 diabetes]] and cancer.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Guevara-Aguirre J, Balasubramanian P, Guevara-Aguirre M, Wei M; et al. | year = 2011| title = Growth hormone receptor deficiency is associated with a major reduction in pro-aging signaling, cancer, and diabetes in humans | journal = Sci. Transl. Med. | volume = 3 | issue = 70 | pages = 70–83 | doi=10.1126/scitranslmed.3001845}}</ref> Lastly, human [[centenarians]] around the world are disproportionately of [[short stature]], and have low levels of IGF-1.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Govindaraju D, Atzmon G, Barzilai N. | year = 2015| title =Genetics, lifestyle and longevity: Lessons from centenarians.| journal = Appl Transl Genom. | volume = 4| issue = | pages = 23–32 | doi=10.1016/j.atg.2015.01.001}}</ref>
===Reproduction and aging=== Numerous studies have found that lifespan is inversely correlated with both the total amount of offspring birthed, as well as the age at which females first gives birth, also known as primiparity.<ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite journal |authors=Descamps S, Boutin S, Berteaux D, Gaillard JM.| year = 2006| title =Best squirrels trade a long life for an early reproduction| journal = Proc Biol Sci | volume = 273| issue = 1599 | pages = 2369–2374 | doi= 10.1098/rspb.2006.3588}}</ref> Additionally, it has been found that [[Sexual reproduction|reproduction]] is a costly mechanism that alters the [[Fatty acid metabolism|metabolism of fat]]. [[Lipids]] invested in reproduction would be unable to be allocated to support mechanisms involved in somatic maintenance.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Hansen M, Flatt T, Aguilaniu H.| year = 2013| title =Reproduction, fat metabolism, and life span: what is the connection?| journal = Cell Metab.| volume = 17| issue = 1 | pages = 10–19 | doi= 10.1016/j.cmet.2012.12.003}}</ref>
==== Animal models ====
The disposable soma theory has been consistent with the majority of animal models. It was found in numerous animal studies that [[castration]] or [[Genetic disorder|genetic deformities]] of [[Reproductive system|reproduction organs]] was [[correlated]] with increased lifespan.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Drori D, Folman Y.| year = 1976| title =Environmental effects on longevity in the male rat: exercise, mating, castration and restricted feeding| journal = Exp Gerontol.| volume = 11| issue = 1 | pages = 25–32}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |authors=Flatt T| year = 2011| title =Survival costs of reproduction in ''Drosophila''.| journal = Exp Gerontol.| volume = 46| issue = 5 | pages = 369–375 | doi= 10.1016/j.exger.2010.10.008}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |authors=Hsin H, Kenyon C| year = 1999| title =Signals from the reproductive system regulate the lifespan of ''C. elegans''| journal =Nature| volume =399| issue = 6734 | pages = 362–366 | doi= 10.1038/20694| bibcode =1999Natur.399..362H}}</ref> Moreover, in [[red squirrels]], it was found that females with an early primiparity achieved the highest immediate and lifetime reproductive success. However, it was also found that these same individuals had a decreased median and maximum lifespan. Specifically squirrels who mated earlier had a 22.4% rate of mortality until two years of age compared to a 16.5% rate of mortality in late breeders. In addition, these squirrels had an average maximum lifespan of 1035 days compared to an average maximum lifespan of 1245 days for squirrels that bred later.<ref name="ReferenceB" />
In another study, researchers selectively bred [[Drosophila melanogaster|fruit flies]] over three years to develop two different [[strain (biology)|strain]]s, an early-reproducing strain and a late-reproducing strain. The late-reproducing line had a significantly longer lifespan than the early-reproducing line. Even more telling was that when the researchers introduced a mutation in the [[Ovarian|ovarian-associated]] gene ''ovoD1'', resulting in defective [[oogenesis]], the differences in lifespan between the two lines disappeared. The researchers in this case concluded that "aging has evolved primarily because of the damaging effects of reproduction earlier in life".<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Sgrò CM, Partridge L| year = 1999| title = A delayed wave of death from reproduction in Drosophila.| journal =Science| volume =286| issue =5449 | pages = 2521–2524 }}</ref>
Prominent aging researcher [[Steven N. Austad|Steven Austad]] also performed a large-scale [[ecological]] study on the [[coast]] of [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] in 1993. Austad isolated two [[opossum]] populations, one from the [[predator]]-infested mainland and one from the predator-absent nearby island of [[Sapelo]]. According to the disposable soma theory, a [[Genetic isolate|genetically isolated]] population subject to low environmentally-induced mortality would evolve delayed reproduction and aging. This is because without the pressure of predation, it would be evolutionarily advantageous to allocate more resources to somatic maintenance than reproduction, as early offspring mortality would be low. As predicted, even after controlling for predation, the isolated population had a longer lifespan, delayed primiparity, and reduced aging biomarkers such as tail [[collagen]] [[Cross linking|cross-linking]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Austad, SN| year = 1993| title =Retarded senescence in an insular population of Virginia opossums (''Didelphis virginiana'')| journal = Journal of Zoology| volume = 229| issue = 4 | pages = 695–708 | doi= 10.1111/j.1469-7998.1993.tb02665.x}}</ref>
====Human models ====
In general, only a few studies exist in human models. It was found that [[Eunuch|castrated men]] live longer than their [[fertile]] counterparts.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Hamilton JB, Mestler GE| year = 1969| title =Mortality and survival: comparison of eunuchs with intact men and women in a mentally retarded population)| journal = J. Gerontol.| volume = 24| issue = 4 | pages = 395–411 }}</ref> Further studies found that in British women, primiparity was earliest in women who died early and latest in women who died at the oldest ages. Furthermore, increased number of children birthed was associated with a decreased lifespan.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Westendorp RG, Kirkwood TB| year = 1998| title =Human longevity at the cost of reproductive success |journal = Nature| volume = 396| issue = 6713 | pages = 743–746 | doi= 10.1038/25519}}</ref> A final study found that female centenarians were more likely to have children in later life compared average, especially past the age of 40. The researchers discovered that 19.2% of female centenarians had their first child after the age of 40, compared to 5.5% of the rest of the female population.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Perls TT, Alpert L, Fretts RC| year = 1997| title =Middle-aged mothers live longer |journal = Nature| volume = 389| issue = 6647 | pages = 133 | doi= 10.1038/38148| bibcode = 1997Natur.389..133P}}</ref>
=== Relationship between cell damage and aging=== {{main|Free radical theory}}{{main|DNA damage theory of aging}} [[File:Naked Mole Rat Eating.jpg|thumb|The [[naked mole rat]] has a [[naked mole rat#Longevity|disproportionately long life of 30 years]] through efficient cellular repair mechanisms.]] There are numerous studies that support cellular damage, often due to a lack of somatic maintenance mechanisms, as a primary determinant for aging, and these studies have given rise to the [[free radical theory of aging]] and the [[DNA damage theory of aging]]. One study found that the cells of short-living rodents ''[[in vitro]]'' show much greater [[mutation]] rates and a general lack of genome surveillance compared to human cells and are far more susceptible to [[oxidative stress]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Lorenzini A, Stamato T, Sell C. | year = 2011| title = The disposable soma theory revisited: time as a resource in the theories of aging | journal = Cell Cycle| volume = 10 | issue = 22 | pages = 3853–3856 | doi=10.4161/cc.10.22.18302}}</ref> Other studies have been conducted on the [[naked mole rat]], a rodent species with remarkable longevity (30 years), capable of outliving the [[brown rat]] (3 years) by [[Fold (higher-order function)|ten-fold]]. Additionally, almost no incidence cancer has ever been detected in naked mole rats. Nearly all of the differences found between these two organisms, which are otherwise rather genetically similar, was in somatic maintenance. Naked mole rats were found to have higher levels of [[superoxide dismutase]], a [[reactive oxygen species]] clearing [[antioxidant]]. In addition, naked mole rats had higher levels of [[base excision repair]], DNA damage response signaling, [[Homologous recombination|homologous recombination repair]], [[mismatch repair]], [[nucleotide excision repair]], and [[non-homologous end joining]]. In fact, many of these processes were near or exceeded human levels. Proteins from naked mole rats were also more resistant to [[oxidation]], [[misfolding]], [[ubiquitination]], and had increased [[Translation|translational fidelity]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Azpurua J, Ke Z, Chen IX, Zhang Q, Ermolenko DN; et al. | year = 2013| title = Naked mole-rat has increased translational fidelity compared with the mouse, as well as a unique 28S ribosomal RNA cleavage | journal = Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A| volume = 110 | issue = 43 | pages =17350–17355 | doi=10.1073/pnas.1313473110| bibcode =2013PNAS..11017350A}}</ref>
Further studies have been conducted on patients with [[Hutchinson-Gilford Progeria Syndrome]] (HGPS), a condition that leads to premature aging. Patients with HGPS typically age about seven times faster than average and usually succumb to the disease in their early teens. Patients with HGPS have cellular defects, specifically in the [[Lamin A protein|lamin proteins]], which regulate the organization of the [[Nuclear lamina|lamina]] and [[nuclear envelope]] for [[mitosis]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Pollex RL1, Hegele RA | year = 2004| title = Hutchinson-Gilford progeria syndrome | journal = Clin. Genet.| volume = 66| issue = 5 | pages =375–381 | doi=10.1111/j.1399-0004.2004.00315.x}}</ref>
Lastly, as mentioned previously, it has been found that the suppression of autophagy is associated with reduced lifespan, while stimulation is associated with extended lifespan. Activated in times of [[caloric restriction]], autophagy is a process that prevents cellular damage through clearance and [[recycling]] of damaged proteins and [[organelles]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Glick D1, Barth S, Macleod KF. | year = 2010| title = Autophagy: cellular and molecular mechanisms| journal = J. Pathol. | volume = 221 | issue = 1 | pages =3–12| doi=10.1002/path.2697}}</ref>
== Criticism== One of the main weaknesses of the disposable soma theory is that it does not postulate any specific cellular mechanisms to which an organism shifts energy to somatic repair over reproduction. Instead, it only offers an [[Evolution|evolutionary perspective]] on why aging may occur due to reproduction. Therefore, parts of it are rather limited outside of the field of [[evolutionary biology]].<ref name="ReferenceC" />
===Caloric restriction=== {{main|Calorie restriction#Sirtuin-mediated mechanism}} [[File:Soma Disposable.png|thumb|Schematic showing the reallocation of energy investment towards [[DNA repair|self-repair]] during [[caloric restriction]].]] Critics have pointed out the supposed [[Inconsistency|inconsistencies]] of the disposable soma theory due to the observed effects of caloric restriction, which is correlated with increased lifespan.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Blagosklonny, MV| year = 2010| title = Solving puzzles of aging: From disposable soma to signal-transduction pathways| journal = Russ J Gen Chem. | volume = 80 | issue = | pages =1407}}</ref> Although it activates autophagy, according to classical disposable soma principles, with less [[Caloric|caloric intake]], there would less total energy to be distributed towards somatic maintenance, and decreased lifespan would be observed (or at least the positive autophagic effects would be balanced out). However, Kirkwood, alongside his collaborator Darryl P. Shanley, assert that caloric restriction triggers an adaptive mechanism which causes the organism to shift a higher proportion of resources to somatic maintenance, away from reproduction.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Shanley DP, Kirkwood TB.| year = 2000| title = Calorie restriction and aging: a life-history analysis.| journal = Evolution | volume = 54 | issue =3 | pages =1407}}</ref> This theory is supported by multiple studies, which show that caloric restriction typically results in [[Sterility (physiology)|impaired fertility]], but leave an otherwise healthy organism.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Holliday R.| year = 2000| title = Food, reproduction and longevity: is the extended lifespan of calorie-restricted animals an evolutionary adaptation?| journal = BioEssays | volume = 10 | issue =4 | pages =125–127|doi=10.1002/bies.950100408}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |authors=Masoro EJ, Austad SN.| year = 1996| title = The evolution of the antiaging action of dietary restriction: a hypothesis.| journal = J Gerontol A Biol Sci Med Sci | volume = 51 | issue =6 | pages =387–391}}</ref> Evolutionarily, an organism would want to delay reproduction to when resources were more plentiful. During a resource-barren period, it would evolutionarily unwise to invest resources in progeny that would be unlikely to survive in [[famine]]. Mechanistically, the [[Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide|NAD]]-dependent [[Deacetylate|deacetylase]] [[Sirtuin 1]] (SIRT-1) is upregulated during low-nutrient periods. SIRT-1 increases [[insulin sensitivity]], decreases the amount of [[inflammatory cytokine]]s, stimulates autophagy, and activates FOXO, the aforementioned protein involved in activating stress response genes. SIRT-1 is also found to result in decreased fertility.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Cantó C, Auwerx J.| year = 2009| title = Caloric restriction, SIRT1 and longevity.| journal =Trends Endocrinol Metab| volume = 20 | issue =7 | pages =325–331|doi=10.1016/j.tem.2009.03.008}}</ref>
In additional to differential [[wikt:partitioning|partitioning]] of energy allocation during caloric restriction, less caloric intake would result in less metabolic waste in the forms of [[free radicals]] like [[hydrogen peroxide]], [[superoxide]] and [[hydroxyl radicals]], which damage important cellular components, particularly [[mitochondria]]. Elevated levels of free radicals in mice has been correlated with neurodegeneration, [[Myocardial|myocardial injury]], [[Anemia|severe anemia]], and premature death.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Pérez VI, Bokov A, Van Remmen H, Mele J; et al.| year = 2009| title = Is the oxidative stress theory of aging dead?| journal =Biochim Biophys Acta| volume = 1790 | issue =10 | pages =1005–1014|doi=10.1016/j.bbagen.2009.06.003}}</ref>
===The Grandmother hypothesis=== {{main|Menopause#Evolutionary rationale}} Another primary criticism of the disposable soma theory is that it fails to account for why women tend to live longer than their male counterparts.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Ginter E, Simko V | year = 2013| title = Women live longer than men| journal = Bratisl Lek Listy. | volume = 114 | issue = 2 | pages =45–49}}</ref> Afterall, females invest significantly more resources into reproduction and according to the classical disposable soma principles, this would compromise energy diverted to somatic maintenance. However, this can be reconciled with the [[grandmother hypothesis]]. The Grandmother Hypothesis states that [[menopause]] comes about into older women in order to restrict the time of reproduction as a protective mechanism. This would allow women to live longer and increase the amount of care they could provide to their [[grandchildren]], increasing their evolutionary fitness.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Hawkes K | year = 2003| title = Grandmothers and the evolution of human longevity| journal = Am. J. Hum. Biol.| volume =15 | issue =3 | pages =380–400| doi= 10.1002/ajhb.10156}}</ref> And so, although women do invest a greater proportion of resources into reproduction during their [[Age and female fertility|fertile years]], their overall reproductive period is significantly shorter than men, who are able of reproduction during and even beyond [[middle age]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Vinicius L, Mace R, Migliano A| year = 2014| title = Variation in Male Reproductive Longevity across Traditional Societies| journal = PLoS One| volume =9 | issue =11 | pages =e112236| doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0112236| bibcode =2014PLoSO...9k2236V}}</ref> Additionally, males invest more resources into growth, and have significantly higher levels of IGF-1 compared to females, which is correlated with decreased lifespan. Other variables such as increased [[Testosterone|testosterone levels]] in males are not accounted for. Increased testosterone is often associated with reckless behaviour, which may lead to a high accidental death rate.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Celec P, Ostatníková D, Hodosy J. | year = 2015| title = On the effects of testosterone on brain behavioral functions| journal = Front. Neurosci.| volume =9 | issue = | pages =12| doi=10.3389/fnins.2015.00012}}</ref>
=== Contradicting models === A few [[Contradiction|contradicting]] animal models weaken the validity of the disposable soma theory. This includes studies done on the aforementioned naked mole rats. In these studies, it was found that reproductive naked mole rats actually show significantly increased lifespans compared to non-reproductive individuals, which contradicts the principles of diposable soma. However, although these naked mole rats are [[mammalian]], they are highly [[atypical]] in terms of aging studies and may not serve as the best model for humans. For example, naked mole rats have a disproportionately high longevity quotient and live in [[Eusociality|eusocial societies]], where breeding is usually designated to a [[Eusociality#In mammals|queen]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Dammann P, Burda H | year = 2006| title =Sexual activity and reproduction delay ageing in a mammal.| journal = Curr. Biol.| volume = 16 | issue = 4 | pages = 117–118 | doi=10.1016/j.cub.2006.02.012}}</ref>
=== Sex biases and environment === The disposable soma theory is tested disproportionately on female organisms for the relationship between reproduction and aging, as [[Parental investment#Females as the more investing sex|females carry a greater burden in reproduction]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Hammers M, Richardson DS, Burke T, Komdeur J. | year = 2013| title = The impact of reproductive investment and early-life environmental conditions on senescence: support for the disposable soma hypothesis.| journal = J Evol Biol | volume = 26| issue = 9 | pages = 1999–2007| doi=10.1111/jeb.12204}}</ref> Additionally, for the relationship between growth and aging, studies are disproportionately conducted on males, to minimize the [[Estrogen|hormonal fluctuations]] that occur with [[Menstrual cycle|menstrual cycling]].<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Wu JJ, Liu J, Chen EB, Wang JJ; et al. | year = 2013| title = Increased mammalian lifespan and a segmental and tissue-specific slowing of aging after genetic reduction of mTOR expression| journal = Cell Rep. | volume = 4| issue = 5 | pages = 913–920| doi=10.1016/j.celrep.2013.07.030}}</ref> Lastly, [[aging#Biological basis|genetic]] and [[Gene–environment interaction|environmental factors]], rather than reproductive patterns, may explain the variations in human lifespan. For example, studies have shown that [[Poverty|poorer individuals]], to whom nutritious food and [[medical care]] is less accessible, typically have higher birth rates and earlier primiparity.<ref>{{cite journal |authors=Murray, S. | year = 2006| title = Poverty and health| journal = CMAJ | volume = 174| issue = 7 | pages = 923| doi=10.1503/cmaj.060235}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links==
===Calorie restriction=== *[https://www.crsociety.org Calorie Restriction Society].
===Biology of Aging=== *[http://www.senescence.info/causes_of_aging.html Damage-Based Theories of Aging] Includes a discussion of the free radical theory of aging.
{{senescence}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Free-Radical Theory}} [[Category:Senescence]] [[Category:Free radicals|*]] [[Category:Theories of aging]] [[Category:Theories of biological aging]] [[Category:Proximate theories of biological aging]] [[Category:Evolution]]

{{Infobox mineral | name = Dorrite | boxwidth = | boxbgcolor = purple | image = | imagesize = | alt = | caption = | category = [[Inosilicate]]
Sapphirine supergroup | formula = Ca2Mg2Fe43+(Al4Si2)O22 | molweight = 893.97 g/mol | strunz = 9.DH.40 | dana = 69.2.1a.2 | system = [[Triclinic]]
Unknown space group | unit cell = a = 9.98, b = 5.08
c = 5.24 [Å]; β = 99.9° | color = Dark red-brown to dark brown | colour = | habit = Anhedral; Small prismatic [[crystals]]; Pseudomonoclinic | twinning = Common, producing a pseudomonoclinic symmetry | cleavage = Good cleavage assumed to be parallel to {010} and {001} | fracture = Irregular | tenacity = | mohs = 5 | luster = Submetallic | streak = Grey | diaphaneity = Subopaque | gravity = | density = 3.959 g/cm3 | polish = | opticalprop = | refractive = α=1.82
β=1.84
γ=1.86 | birefringence = δ = 0.040 | pleochroism = X=red-orange to brown
Y=yellowish brown
Z=greenish brown | 2V = 90° | dispersion = | extinction = | length fast/slow = | fluorescence = | absorption = Very strong | melt = | fusibility = | diagnostic = | solubility = | impurities = | alteration = | other = | prop1 = | prop1text = | var1 = | var1text = | var2 = | var2text = | var3 = | var3text = | var4 = | var4text = | var5 = | var5text = | var6 = | var6text = | references = {{Cite journal |last1=Cosca |first1=Michael A. |last2=Rouse |first2=Roland R. |last3=Essene |first3=Eric J. |date=December 1988 |title=Dorrite [Ca2 (Mg2 Fe3+4)(Al4Si2) O20], a new member of the aenigmatite group from a pyrometamorphic melt-rock |journal=American Mineralogist |volume=73 |issue=11-12 |pages=1440–1448}}{{cite web|url=http://webmineral.com/data/Dorrite.shtml#.VmtUNfkrKM9|title=Dorrite Mineral Data |last=Barthelmy |first=Dave |work=webmineral.com |accessdate=11 December 2015}} }} '''Dorrite''' is a silicate [[mineral]] that is [[isostructural]] to the [[aenigmatite]] group. Although it is most chemically similar to the mineral [[rhönite]] [Ca2Mg5Ti(Al2Si4)O20], the lack of titanium (Ti) and presence of Fe3+ influenced dorrite's independence. Dorrite is named for Dr. John (Jack) A. Dorr, a late professor at the [[University of Michigan]] that researched in [[outcrops]] where dorrite was found in 1982. This mineral is sub-metallic resembling colors of brownish-black, dark brown, to reddish brown. ==Discovery== Dorrite was first reported in 1982 by A. Havette in a basalt-limestone [[Contact (geology)|contact]] on Réunion Island off of the coast of Africa. The second report of dorrite was made by Franklin Foit and his associates while examining a paralava from the [[Powder River Basin]], Wyoming in 1987. Analyses determined that this newly found mineral was surprisingly similar to the mineral rhönite, lacking Ti but presenting dominant Fe3+ in its [[octahedral]] sites. Other minerals that coexist with this phase are [[plagioclase]], [[gehlenite]]-[[Åkermanite|akermanite]], [[magnetite]]-magnesioferrite-spinel solid solutions, [[esseneite]], [[nepheline]], [[wollastonite]], Ba-rich [[feldspar]], [[apatite]], [[ulvöspinel]], ferroan [[sahamalite]], and secondary [[barite]], and [[calcite]]. ==Occurrence== Dorrite can be found in mineral reactions that relate dorrite + [[magnetite]] + [[clinopyroxene]], rhönite + [[magnetite]] + [[olivine]] + [[clinopyroxene]], and [[aenigmatite]] + [[pyroxene]] + [[olivine]] assemblages in nature. These assemblages favor low pressures and high temperatures. Dorrite is stable in strongly [[oxidizing]], high-temperature, low-pressure environments. It occurs in paralava, pyrometamorphic melt rock, formed from the burning of [[coal]] beds. ==Crystallography== Researchers conclusively determined that dorrite is triclinic-pseudomonoclinic and twinned by a twofold rotation about the pseudomonoclinic b axis. The parameters for dorrite are a=10.505, b=10.897, c=9.019 Å, α=106.26°, β=95.16°, γ=124.75°. ===Chemical Composition=== '''Calcium''' 8.97%
'''Magnesium''' 5.44%
'''Aluminum''' 6.04%
'''Iron''' 37.48%
'''Silicon''' 6.28%
'''Oxygen''' 35.79% ====Oxides==== '''CaO''' 12.55%
'''MgO''' 9.02%
'''Al2O3''' 11.41%
'''Fe2O3''' 53.59%
'''SiO2''' 13.44% ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Natural materials]] [[Category:Inosilicates]] [[Category:Triclinic minerals]]

revision.text:
This is a list of some [[long-distance footpath]]s used for [[walking]] and [[hiking]].
==Africa==
===Namibia=== *[[Fish River Canyon]]
===South Africa=== *[[Otter Trail]] *[[Grand Traverse (South Africa)|Grand Traverse]], a 204 Kilometre (127 mi) walk in the [[Drakensberg]]
===Egypt=== *[[Sinai Trail]], a 250km thru-hike in Sinai from Nuweiba to St. Catherine mountain (Egypt highest summit)<ref>http://www.sinaitrail.org</ref>
==Asia==
===Bhutan=== *328 kilometers (216 mi) [[Snowman Trek]], a 21-day hike through the [[Himalayas]] [https://web.archive.org/web/20130502110011/http://www.nationalgeographic.com/adventure/adventure-travel/asia/bhutan-kira-salak.html]
====Hong Kong==== The merit of hiking trails in Hong Kong is that hikers can enjoy scenery of both the sea and highland. *[[Hong Kong Trail]]: across [[Hong Kong Island]] ({{convert|50|km}}) *[[Lantau Trail]]: on [[Lantau Island]] ({{convert|70|km}}) *[[Wilson Trail]]: from [[Stanley, Hong Kong|Stanley]], [[Hong Kong Island]] to [[Nam Chung]], [[New Territories]] ({{convert|78|km}}) *[[MacLehose Trail]]: from [[Sai Kung]] to [[Tuen Mun]] ({{convert|100|km}})
===Georgia===
Transcaucasian Trail:
A long distance trail in the caucasus has been a lingering idea for trekkers and hikers for many years since they started hiking remote parts of the Caucasus. Many sections of the TCT already exist, used by local community members and shepherds for centuries. These trail cross long valleys and traverse mammoth mountains to connect mountain villages together. Unfortunately, in recent years many of these trails have fallen into disrepair, and while many trails are known to locals, they are difficult to navigate for visitors and tourists. In 2015, two Peace Corps volunteers, Paul Stephens and Jeff Haack, mapped and charted known routes in The Republic of Georgia. During this time they succeeded in locating many connections between known trails and publicizing the concept of the trail. In 2016, Tom Allen and Alessandro Mambelli scouted new trail routes in Armenia while the first trail building project began in Svaneti, Georgia. In 2017, the trail building expanded to Dilijan National Park in Armenia while trail building continued in the Svaneti region. Today, over 300 km of trail has been improved and marked in Georgia and Armenia. Many 7-10 day guided hikes are available on the TCT this summer. Over the next 5 years, the trail will be expanded to connect all of the sections and create even longer hikes. The TCT can serve many purposes in the Caucasus region. For one, the natural diversity of the area needs to be protected. This habitat fosters many species of animal and provides unique ecosystems created by the mountains. More information about the trail can be found at transcaucasiantrail.org . Donations can be sustaining or one-time.
===Israel=== *[[Israel National Trail]]: {{convert|1000|km}}, all of them inside the [[Green Line (Israel)|Green Line]], from kibbutz [[Dan (kibbutz)|Dan]] to [[Eilat]] (north to south), covering many historic and scenic points including some urban areas. *[[Jerusalem Trail]]: {{convert|40|km|adj=on}} trail, connects the Israel National Trail with Jerusalem and the area of the old city. *[[Jesus Trail]]: {{convert|65|km}} in the Galilee region, connecting important sites from the life of Jesus. The trail begins in [[Nazareth]] and passes through [[Sepphoris]], [[Cana]], the horns of [[Hattin]], [[Arbel]] Cliffs, [[Capernaum]], [[Tabgha]], the [[Mount of Beatitudes]], the [[Jordan River]], and [[Mount Tabor]]. *[[Golan Trail]]: {{convert|130|km}} from Mt. Hermon (1500m) to the sea of Galilee (-200m) *[[Sea to sea trail]]: {{convert|70|km}} from the [[sea of Galilee]] to the [[Mediterranean Sea]] *[[Valley of the springs TRail]] (Emek HaMaayanot). A trek of about 140 km, around the Valley of springs near the See of Galilee. *[[Haifa Wadis Trail]]: {{convert|50|km|adj=on}} trail, connecting the Israel National Trail with Haifa and its surroundings.
===Japan=== *[[Hokkaidō Nature Trail]]: {{convert|4585|km}} all over the island of Hokkaidō(planning) *[[Tōhoku Nature Trail]]: {{convert|4374|km}} within prefectures of Aomori, Iwate, Miyagi, Akita, Yamagata and Fukushima *[[Chubu Hokuriku Nature Trail]]: {{convert|4029|km}} within prefectures of Gunma, Niigata, Toyama, Ishikawa, Fukui, Nagano, Gifu and Shiga *[[Kantō Fureai Trail]]: {{convert|1665|km}} within prefectures of Ibaraki, Tochigi, Gunma, Saitama, Chiba, Tōkyō and Kanagawa. Also known as the Capital Region Nature Trail.<ref>http://ja.japantourist.jp/view/the-kanto-fureai-no-michi-in-tokyo</ref> *[[Tōkaidō Nature Trail]]: {{convert|1697|km}} from Tokyo to Osaka via prefectures of Kanagawa, Yamanashi, Shizuoka, Aichi, Shiga, Gifu, Mie, Kyōto and Nara *[[Kinki Nature Trail]]: {{convert|3291|km}} within prefectures of Fukui, Mie, Shiga, Kyōto, Osaka, Hyōgo, Nara, Wakayama and Tottori *[[Chugoku Nature Trail]]: {{convert|2211|km}} within prefectures of Tottori, Shimane, Okayama, Hiroshima and Yamaguchi *[[Shikoku Nature Trail]]: {{convert|1637|km}} within prefectures of Ehime, Tokushima, Kagawa and Kōchi *[[Kyushu Nature Trail]]: {{convert|2587|km}} within prefectures of Fukuoka, Saga, Nagasaki, Kumamoto, Oita, Miyazaki and Kagoshima
===Jordan=== *600 kilometers (372 mi) [[Jordan Trail]]: north-south, cross country from Um Qais to Aqaba<ref>Route descriptions, maps, photos, etc. at [http://www.jordantrail.org/ jordantrail.org]</ref>
===Lebanon=== *[[Lebanon Mountain Trail]], a 26-day {{convert|440|km|adj=on}} trail through [[Mount Lebanon]]
===Malaysia=== *[[Grand Malaysia Trail]] (Kai Pengembara Negara-Kai Trails Around Malaysia): nationwide trail of more than {{convert|3000|km}} length
===Myanmar=== [[Hkakabo Razi]] Trail, climbing the highest peak in Myanmar, in [[Khakaborazi National Park]], and various footpaths in [[Putao]]
===Nepal=== *{{convert|4500|km}} [[The Great Himalaya Trail]] (GHT) is proposed to follow the Greater Himalaya Range from Namche Barwa in [[Tibet]] to Nanga Parbat in [[Pakistan]] forming the world's highest mountain trail. It will connect five Asian countries: [[Bhutan]], [[China]], [[India]], [[Nepal]], and Pakistan. It uses existing trails, many of which are trekking, trade, or pilgrimage routes, but no new trails have been built. Starting near [[Kangchenjunga|Kanchenjunga]] in the east and ending in [[Humla District|Humla]] in the west, the Nepal section has been walked and documented and is about {{convert|1600|km}}. (See the [http://www.thegreathimalayatrail.org/ Great Himalaya Trail website] and the [http://www.greathimalayatrail.com/ Great Himalaya Trail book website].) *Trek to [[Everest Base Camp]], an 18-day trail to the base camp of Mt. Everest (see [http://www.expeditionnepal.com/en/nepal/trekking/everest-base-camp-trek Everest Base Camp Trek at WikiVoyage]|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}) *230 kilometers (145 mi) [[Annapurna Circuit]], a 3-week loop trek through the [[Annapurna]] range (see [https://www.himalayastrek.com/annapurna-circuit-trekking/ Annapurna Circuit at WikiVoyage]) *277 kilometers (173 mi) [[Manaslu Circuit]], a 3-week loop trek through the adjacent range to the [[Annapurna]] region—the [[Manaslu]] region.
===Russia=== *[[Great Baikal Trail]] *[[Frolikha Adventure Coastline Track]] F.A.C.T.: {{convert|100|km}} trail at the northern tip of [[Lake Baikal]]
===South Korea=== * The [[Baekdudaegan]] Trail: {{convert|750|km}} along the ridge of the Baekdu Daegan mountain range, Korea's watershed divide. * [[Olle road|The Jeju Olle]] (400 km) is a series of connected walking courses that circumnavigate the coastline of Jeju Island.
===Turkey=== *[[Sufi Trail]] - 801 km trail from [[Istanbul]] to [[Konya]], following the Ottoman Sultans [[Hajj]] route *[[Lycian Way]] - 540 km trail around the south coast of Turkey *[[Saint Paul Trail]] - 500 km trail following [[Paul the Apostle|St Paul]]'s 1st journey *[http://www.sultanstrail.com Sultans Trail] - from Vienna to İstanbul, following the Ottoman Sultans *[http://cultureroutesinturkey.com/c/hittite-trail/ Hittite Trail - in central Turkey on ancient Hittite roads] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20140924050937/http://cultureroutesinturkey.com/c/kackar-mountains-trails/ Kackar Trails - 8 multi-day trails in Northeast Turkey] *[[Evliya Çelebi Way]] - the first part of [[Evliya Çelebi|Evliya]]'s route to Mecca in the 17th century *[http://cultureroutesinturkey.com/c/phrygian-way/ Phrygian Way - 600km route around the Phrygian Valleys near Ankara] *[http://www.cariantrail.com Carian Trail - 800km trail around the south-west coast of Turkey] *[http://www.abrahampath.org Abraham Path - international route starting in Urfa, southeast Turkey] *[http://www.trekkinginturkey.com Trekking in Turkey - website of Turkish trekking routes] *[http://www.trekkingararat.com Trekking Ararat - Trekking guide service in Turkey] *[http://trekopedia.com/?page_id=471 Trekopedia - Trail reference database that covers the Lycian Way]
==Europe== *The [[GR footpath]]s in [[Belgium]], [[France]], [[Spain]] and the [[Netherlands]] *[[European long-distance paths]], over 70.000 km of 12 long-distance E-paths. *The [[Tour du Mont Blanc]] circles the Mont Blanc Massif covering a distance of roughly 170 kilometres (110 mi) with 10 kilometres (6.2 mi) of ascent/descent and passes through parts of Switzerland, Italy and France *The ''[[Haute Randonnée Pyrénéenne]]'' (HRP) in the [[Pyrenees]] in France, Spain and [[Andorra]] *{{convert|800|km}} [[Nordkalottleden Trail]] (Kalottireitti) in the northernmost parts of [[Finland]], [[Sweden]], and [[Norway]] ([[Sápmi (area)|Lapland]]) *{{convert|2530|km}} Camino de Santiago de Compostela, or [[St James's Way]], commonly walked through France and Spain, but including old pilgrimage [[Way of St. James (route descriptions)|routes]] from as far afield as [[Poland]] and [[Portugal]], and adding as many as {{convert|1906|km}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20061211032003/http://www.peterrobins.co.uk/camino/] *''Peaks of the Balkans Trail'', through [[Montenegro]], [[Albania]] and [[Kosovo]] *{{convert|2200|km}} [[Sultans Trail]] in [[Austria]], [[Slovakia]], [[Hungary]], [[Croatia]], [[Serbia]], [[Romania]], [[Bulgaria]], [[Greece]], and [[Turkey]] *{{convert|5000|km}} The [[Via Alpina]] network of Alpine trails **{{convert|1500|km}} Red Trail [http://www.backpackinglight.com/cgi-bin/backpackinglight/via_alpina_not_another_walk_in_the_woods.html#.UXcTvoVBEy5] **Violet Trail **Yellow Trail **Green Trail **Blue Trail *[[Via Francigena]] from Canterbury to Rome * [[:it:Tratturo L'Aquila-Foggia]] from L'Aquila (Abruzzo region, Italy) to Foggia (Puglia region, Italy). At 244 km, Tratturo Magno is the longest and the most important ancient route, traversed by shepherds in [[Transhumance]]
===Austria=== *[[Arnoweg]] around the Austrian Alps *[[Alpe Adria Trail]], Austria, Slovenia, Italy *[[North Alpine Trail]] *[[Central Alpine Trail]] *[[South Alpine Trail]] *[[North South Path]] *[[East Austrian Borderland Trail]] *[[Sultans Trail]] Austria, Slovakia, Hungary, Croatia, Serbia, Romania, Bulgaria, Greece and Turkey *[[Way of the book]]
===Bulgaria=== *[[Kom-Emine]] {{convert|700|km}}, from Mount Kom to [[Cape Emine]] (part of [[European walking route E3]])<ref>[http://www.walkingworld.co.uk/home/index.asp?id=32&nid=183 KOM-EMINE] from Walkingworld</ref> *[[Sultans Trail]] Austria, Slovakia, Hungary, Croatia, Serbia, Romania, Bulgaria, Greece and Turkey
===Croatia=== *[[Sultans Trail]] Austria, Slovakia, Hungary, Croatia, Serbia, Romania, Bulgaria, Greece and Turkey
===Czechia=== *[[Polish - Czech Friendship Trail]]: trail along the Polish and Czech border in [[Sudetes]]
===Denmark=== *[[Hærvejen]], ancient trail on the [[Jutland Peninsula]]. *[[Øhavsstien]] 220 km around the archipelago of southern Denmark [[Fünen]]. *[[Gendarmstien]], 74 km following the border between Germany and Denmark. *[https://bornholmrundt.dk Bornholm Rundt]. A walk around of the island of [[Bornholm]] (120 km). *[http://camoenoen.dk Camønoen] A walk on the island of Møn (175 km).
=== Estonia === * [[Peraküla, Lääne County|Peraküla]]-[[Aegviidu]]-[[Ähijärve]], 820 kilometres from North-East to South-West Estonia<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://loodusegakoos.ee/where-to-go/hiking-route/perakula-aegviidu-ahijarve-hiking-route|title=Loodusega Koos|website=Loodusega Koos|access-date=2017-06-05}}</ref> * [[Oandu, Lääne-Viru County|Oandu]]-[[Aegviidu]]-[[Ikla]], 375 kilometres from North to South Estonia<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://loodusegakoos.ee/where-to-go/hiking-route/oandu-aegviidu-ikla-hiking-route|title=Loodusega Koos|website=Loodusega Koos|access-date=2017-06-05}}</ref>
===Finland=== *The [[Karhunkierros]] Trail ({{convert|80|km}}, [https://web.archive.org/web/20070310220324/http://www.luontoon.fi/page.asp?Section=7494 External link]) in the municipalities of [[Kuusamo]] and [[Salla]], Oulanka National Park, [[Lapland, Finland|Lapland]] *The Peuran polku Trail: ({{convert|115|km}}, [https://web.archive.org/web/20061007161511/http://www.luontoon.fi/page.asp?Section=5319 External link]) in the municipalities of Kivijärvi, Kinnula, Perho, Lestijärvi and Reisjärvi in [[Central Finland]], [[Central Ostrobothnia]], and [[Northern Ostrobothnia]]—a part of [[European walking route E6]]
===France=== * [[GR footpath#France: Grande Randonnée|Sentier de Grande Randonnée (GR)]] * [[Haute Randonnée Pyrénéenne]] (HRP): High Pyrenees Trail, along the border with Spain. * The [[Tour du Lot]]: a circuit of over {{convert|500|km}} around the Department of the Lot's periphery. * [[Metropolitan Trail|Sentier Métropolitain]]: urban and suburban hiking routes, that allow their users to discover a metropolitan territory in several days of hiking.
===Germany=== * Barbarossaweg: Korbach to Kyffhäuserdenkmal ({{convert|332|km}}) * Bergischer Weg: Essen to Königswinter ({{convert|137|km}}) * [[Birkenhainer Strasse]]: Hanau to Gemünden am Main ({{convert|71|km}}) * Bonifatiusweg: Mainz to Fulda ({{convert|180|km}}) * Christine-Koch-Weg: Menden to Bad Laasphe ({{convert|123|km}}) * [[Eselsweg]]: Schlüchtern to Großheubach ({{convert|111|km}}) *[[König-Ludwig-Weg]]: Berg am Starnberger See to Füssen ({{convert|120|km}}) *[[Maximiliansweg]]: Lindau to Berchtesgaden ({{convert|350|km}}) *[[Moselhöhenweg]]: Trier to Koblenz *[[Pandurensteig]]: Waldmuenchen to Passau *[[Rennsteig]]: Hörsel to Blankenstein/Saale through the Thuringian Forest ({{convert|169|km}}) *[[Rheinburgenweg Trail]]: Bingen to Koblenz to Rüdesheim am Rhein (''c''.{{convert|200|km}}) *[[Rheinhöhenweg Trail]]: Bonn to Alsheim/Wiesbaden ({{convert|530|km}}) *[[Rheinsteig]]: Bonn to Wiesbaden ({{convert|320|km}}) *[[Westweg]] (Black Forest western ridgeway): Pforzheim to Basel ({{convert|279|km}}) *[[Mittelweg]] (Black Forest central ridgeway): Pforzheim to Waldshut ({{convert|233|km}}) *[[Ostweg]] (Black Forest eastern ridgeway): Pforzheim to Schaffhausen ({{convert|238|km}}) *[[Black Forest North Perimeter Way]]: Mühlacker to Karlsruhe ({{convert|71|km}}) * [[Freiburg-Lake Constance Black Forest Trail]]: Freiburg to Konstanz ({{convert|183|km}}) *[[Saar-Hunsrück-Steig]]: Trier to Saarschleife in Mettlach or Idar-Oberstein 9 ({{convert|180|km}})
===Greece=== *[[European walking route E4]] ([[Florina]] to [[Agios Nikolaos, Crete|Agios Nikolaos]]) *[[European walking route E6]] ([[Igoumenitsa]] to [[Alexandroupoli]]) *[[Sultans Trail]] Austria, Slovakia, Hungary, Croatia, Serbia, Romania, Bulgaria, Greece and Turkey
===Hungary=== *[[Countrywide Blue Tour in Hungary]] (part of European long-distance footpath [[European walking route E4|E4]]) *[[Sultans Trail]] Austria, Slovakia, Hungary, Croatia, Serbia, Romania, Bulgaria, Greece and Turkey
===Iceland=== *[[Laugavegur]] from Landmannalaugar to Thorsmork to Skógar ({{convert|80|km}})
===Italy=== *[[Grand Italian Trail]] (Sentiero Italia): nationwide trail of more than {{convert|6000|km}} length *[[Via Francigena]]: pilgrimage route across Italy to Rome from France *[[Emilia-Romagna]]: [[:it:Via_degli_Dei|Via degli Dei]] is a path (135km, 80mi) that crosses the Apennines from [[Bologna]] to [[Florence]]. * Dolomites: **[http://digilander.libero.it/a1bftx/AltaVia1/html/indexe.htm Dolomites Classical High Route (no.1) from Braies Lake to Belluno] **[http://digilander.libero.it/a2bftx/AltaVia2/html/indexe.htm High Route of the Legends (no.2) from Brixen to Feltre] **[http://www.dolomiti.it/eng/itinerari/altevie/altavia3.htm Dolomites High Route of the Chamoi (no.3) from Villabassa to Longarone] **[https://web.archive.org/web/20110722040430/http://www.infodolomiti.it/dolomiti.run?3B024380-1 Dolomites Grohmann's High Route (no.4) from San Candido in Pusteria to Pieve di Cadore] **[http://www.dolomiti.it/eng/itinerari/altevie/altavia5.htm Dolomites Titans's High Route (no.5) from Sesto in Pusteria to Pieve di Cadore] Dolomites Patera's High Route (no.7) from Ponte nelle Alpi to Tambre d'Alpago] **[http://www.dolomiti.it/eng/itinerari/altevie/altavia8.htm Dolomites High Route of the Heroes (no.8) from Feltre to Bassano del Grappa] **[http://www.dolomiti.it/eng/itinerari/altevie/altavia9.htm Dolomites High Route (n. 9): the Trasversale from Bolzano to Santo Stefano di Cadore] **[http://www.dolomiti.it/eng/itinerari/altevie/altavia10.htm Dolomites High Route (n. 10) of Giudicarie from Bolzano to the Garda Lake] * [[Liguria]]: **[http://digilander.iol.it/lgbftaaaa/5terre/html/indexe.htm Liguria: From Portovenere to Camogli] hiking trail along the sea **[[Alta Via dei Monti Liguri]] **Sentiero Azzurro is a trail along a rugged portion of coast on the [[Italian Riviera]] that connects the five towns known as the [[Cinque Terre]] in Liguria, Italy * [[Lombardy]] **[http://digilander.iol.it/viabftx/viandante/html/indexe.htm ''Il Sentiero del Viandante''] The "Wayfarer's trail" from [[Lecco]] to [[Colico]] on the east side of [[Lake Como]]. **[http://www.lakecomo.it/en/excursions_and_trekking/il_sentiero_delle_4_valli ''Il Sentiero delle 4 Valli''] The "Four Valleys Path" between Lake Como and [[Lake Lugano]] **''[[La Via dei Monti Lariani]]'': The Monti Lariani trail on the west side of Lake Como, from [[Cernobbio]] to [[Sorico]] * [[Piedmont]] **[[Grande Traversata delle Alpi]] (GTA): 55 days in the Alps of Piedmont * [[Tuscany]] ** ''Grande Escursione Appenninica'' (Great Apennines Walk): largely along the ridge of the [[Apennine Mountains]]

===Netherlands=== *[[Zevenwoudenpad]] from Lauwersoog to Steenwijk ({{convert|200|km}}) *[[Pionierspad]] from Steenwijk to Muiden ({{convert|200|km}}) *[[Floris V-pad]] from Amsterdam to Bergen op Zoom ({{convert|245|km}}) *[[Trekvogelpad]] from Bergen aan Zee to Enschede ({{convert|380|km}}) *[[Marskramerpad]] from Bad Bentheim to Den Haag ({{convert|360|km}}) *[[Maarten van Rossumpad]] from 's-Hertogenbosch to Ommen ({{convert|308|km}}) *[[Deltapad]] from Sluis to Hoek van Holland ({{convert|237|km}}) *[[Hollands Kustpad]] from Hoek van Holland to Den Helder ({{convert|213|km}}) *[[Friese Kustpad]] from Stavoren to Lauwersoog ({{convert|131|km}}) *[[Wad- en Wierdenpad]] from Lauwersoog to Nieuweschans ({{convert|123|km}}) *[[Oeverloperpad]] from Rotterdam Europoort to Leerdam ({{convert|232|km}}) *[[Lingepad]] from Leerdam to Nijmegen (German border) ({{convert|98|km}}) *[[Pelgrimspad]] from Amsterdam to Maastricht ({{convert|453|km}}) *[[Zuiderzeepad]] from Enkhuizen to Stavoren ({{convert|400|km}}) *[[Pieterpad]] from Pieterburen to the Sint Pietersberg ({{convert|492|km}}) *[[Noaberpad]] from Nieuweschans to Emmerich ({{convert|363|km}}) *[[Grenslandpad]] from Sluis to Thorn ({{convert|363|km}}) *[[Overijssels Havezatenpad]] from Oldenzaal to Steenwijk ({{convert|272|km}}) *[[Peellandpad]] from 's-Hertogenbosch to Roermond ({{convert|160|km}}) * [[Airbornepad]] from the Belgian border to Arnhem
===Norway=== *[[Jotunheimen Trail]] (Norwegian: "Jotunheimstien"): {{convert|320|km}} from downtown Oslo to Lake Gjende in Jotunheimen *[[Nordkalottruta]] (Finnish: Kalottireitti, Swedish: Nordkalottleden): {{convert|800|km}} from Kautokeino (located in Finnmark, Northern Norway) to Sulitjelma (Norway) or alternately Kvikkjokk (Sweden)
=== Poland === *[[Główny Szlak Sudecki]] (Main Sudety Trail): {{convert|440|km}} in [[Sudetes]] Mountains from [[Świeradów Zdrój]] to [[Prudnik]] *[[Main Beskid Trail|Główny Szlak Beskidzki]] (Main Beskidy Trail): {{convert|519|km}} in [[Beskids]] Mountains, from [[Wołosate]] to [[Ustroń]],<ref>[http://www.czerwonyszlak.republika.pl/opis_trasy.htm Główny Szlak Beskidzki - opis trasy]</ref> the longest public trail in Poland *[[Polish - Czech Friendship Trail]]: trail along the Polish and Czech border in [[Sudetes]]
=== Portugal === * [[Rota Vicentina]]
===Romania=== *[[Sultans Trail]] Austria, Slovakia, Hungary, Croatia, Serbia, Romania, Bulgaria, Greece and Turkey
===Republic of Ireland=== *[[Long-distance trails in the Republic of Ireland]]
===Serbia=== *[[Sultans Trail]] Austria, Slovakia, Hungary, Croatia, Serbia, Romania, Bulgaria, Greece and Turkey * The Fruška Gora Transversal (Serbian: ''Fruškogorska Transverzala'') - circular trail around [[Fruška gora|<nowiki/>]][[Fruška Gora]] mountain - 160 km (100 mi) * The Small Toplica Transversal (Serbian: ''Mala Toplička Transverzala'') - 122 km (76 mi)
===Slovakia=== *[[The Slovak National Uprising Heroes Trail]] {{convert|750|km}} from east to west (Dukla Bradlo) across mountainous regions of Slovakia *[[Sultans Trail]] Austria, Slovakia, Hungary, Croatia, Serbia, Romania, Bulgaria, Greece and Turkey
===Slovenia=== *[[Slovenian Mountain Hiking Trail]] {{convert|599|km}} from east ([[Maribor]]) to west ([[Ankaran]])
===Spain=== * [[Way of St. James]] (Spanish: El Camino de Santiago) * [[Route of the Monasteries of Valencia]] (Spanish: Ruta de los Monasterios de Valencia) * [[Grande Randonnée]] 7 ([[GR 7 (Spain)|GR 7]]): From [[Tarifa]] to the mountain cabin of Fontferrera, part of the [[European walking route E4|E4]] route. * [[Grande Randonnée]] 11 ([[GR 11 (Spain)|GR 11]]): [[Pyrenees]] Trail, staying within Spain. * [[Haute Randonnée Pyrénéenne]] (HRP): High Pyrenees Trail, along the border with France. * [http://www.caminodosfaros.com O Camiño dos Faros (The Lighthouse Way)] : 200 km (124 mi) along the coastline from Malpica to Fisterra, in Galicia (Spain)
===Sweden=== *[[Kungsleden]], {{convert|425|km}} from the northern extremity of the country *[http://www.sormlandsleden.se/default.aspx Sörmlandsleden] {{convert|1000|km}} of winding paths through the county of Sörmland. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100920070341/http://www.nordwinde.de/InfoBohus_eng.html Bohusleden] {{convert|360|km}} past at Göteborg, Uddevalla, Munkedal and ends finally in Strömstad * [[Ingegerdsleden]], 110 kilometres (68 mi), pilgrimage route in county of [[Uppland]] between [[Uppsala Cathedral]] and [[Stockholm Cathedral]]. * [[Skåneleden]], more than {{convert|1000|km}} long path through the province of [[Scania]]. Part of the [[North Sea Trail]].
===Switzerland=== See: [[:Category:Hiking trails in Switzerland|Hiking trails in Switzerland]]
===United Kingdom=== *[[Long-distance footpaths in the United Kingdom]]
==North America==
===Canada=== *420 km (260 mi) long [[Alexander MacKenzie Heritage Trail]] (aka Blackwater Trail) in [[British Columbia]] *Almost 900 km (560 mi) long [[Bruce Trail]] in [[Ontario]] *33-mile (53 km) long [[Chilkoot Trail]] in British Columbia and [[Alaska|Alaska, USA]] *540 kilometres (340 mi) long [[East Coast Trail]] in [[Newfoundland]] *5,400 miles (8,700 km) long [[Eastern Continental Trail]] from Newfoundland to [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia, USA]] *1,200 km long (745 mi) [[Great Divide Trail]] in [[Alberta]] and British Columbia *3058 km (1900 mi) long [[International Appalachian Trail]] from Newfoundland to [[Maine|Maine, USA]] *47 km (29 mi) long [[Juan de Fuca Trail]] in British Columbia *63 km (39 mi) long [[Mantario Trail]] in [[Manitoba]] and Ontario *[[National Hiking Trail of Canada]] [http://www.nationaltrail.ca/] *387-kilometre (240 mi) long [[Rideau Trail]] in Ontario *[[Trans-Canada Trail]] 18,000 kilometres (11,000 mi) long as of February 2016 *600 km (373 mi) long [[Voyageur Hiking Trail]] in Ontario *75 km (47 mi) long [[West Coast Trail]] in British Columbia *78-kilometre (48 mi) long [[La Cloche Silhouette Trail]] in Ontario *41 kilometres (25 mi) long [[Fundy Footpath]] in [[New Brunswick]] *220-kilometre (140 mi) long [[Capital Pathway]] in Ontario and [[Quebec]] *[[Vancouver Island Spine Trail]] in British Columbia *180 km, Sunshine Coast Trail in British Columbia
===Greenland=== *~100 mi (165 km) [[:de:Arctic Circle Trail|Arctic Circle Trail]]
===Panama=== *700-mile [[TransPanama Trail]] [http://planet-wild.com/transpanama-hike-over-700-miles-of-hiking/]
===United States=== *[[Long-distance trails in the United States]]
==Oceania==
===Australia=== See: [[List of long-distance hiking tracks in Australia]]
===New Zealand=== *[[New Zealand tramping tracks]] *[http://www.teararoa.org.nz/index.cfm Te Araroa] {{convert|3000|km}} Stretching from Cape Reinga in the north of New Zealand to Bluff in the South.
==South America==
===Argentina=== *[[Los Glaciares]] ** Various options to Laguna Torre, Cerro FitzRoy, or even out onto the [[Southern Patagonian Ice Field]] *[[Huella Andina]] ** 570 kilometers from [[Alumine Lake]] to [[Baggilt lake]]<ref>http://huellaandina.desarrolloturistico.gov.ar/</ref>
===Bolivia=== *[[Cordillera Real (Bolivia)]] ** 106 kilometres (66 mi) 7-day Illampu Circuit
===Brazil=== *[[Serra dos Órgãos]] ** {{convert|36|km}} between Petrópolis and Teresópolis (medium to hard trail) *[[Transcarioca Trail]] ** {{convert|183|km}} in Rio de Janeiro city (medium to hard trail) <ref>http://trilhatranscarioca.com.br/</ref> *[[Transmantiqueira Trail]] ** {{convert|700|km}} between Extrema and Aiuruoca (very hard trail) <ref>https://www.facebook.com/trilhatransmantiqueira/</ref> *[[Caminho da Fe]] ** {{convert|538| km}}. There are 3 different starting points: *** from Sao Carlos to [[Aparecida]] *** or from Cravinhos to Aparecida *** or from Mococa to Aparecida
===Chile=== *Central Chile and Patagonia **3,000 kilometers (1,850 mi) [[Hiking in Chile#Greater Patagonian Trail|Greater Patagonian Trail]]<ref>{{cite web|last1=Dudeck|first1=Jan|title=Greater Patagonian Trail|url=http://www.wikiexplora.com/index.php/Greater_Patagonian_Trail|website=wikiexplora|accessdate=17 August 2014}}</ref> from the capital Santiago de Chile to the Southern Patagonian Ice Field. *Magallanes **118 kilometers. Full circuit of [[Torres del Paine]], including Valle del Francés and access to the base of Torres del Paine.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Meneses|first1=Patricia|title=Trekking Torres del Paine|url=http://www.wikiexplora.com/index.php/Trekking_Torres_del_Paine|website=Wikiexplora|accessdate=17 August 2014}}</ref> **Dientes de Navarino Circuit ~53km. 3 - 7 days. Starts out of Puerto Williams. Access from mainland Chile by ferry from Punta Areas, plane or from Ushuaia. http://rutas.bienes.cl/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/01.pdf
===Peru=== *[[Cordillera Blanca]] and [[Huayhuash mountain range|Huayhuash]] mountain range near [[Huaráz]] **30 kilometers (19 mi) 10- to 14-day trek on the Huayhuash Circuit **52 kilometers (33 mi) 3- to 4-day "W" Circuit Santa Cruz trek **94 kilometers (59 mi) 6- to 10-day Alpamayo Circuit, full "O" Circuit *[[Sacred Valley]] & [[Vilcanota mountain range]] near [[Cuzco]] **88 kilometers (55 mi) for the longest Mollepata variant of the [[Inca trail]], with options for a single day to more than six days, all ending at [[Machu Picchu]] **32 kilometers (20 mi) Cachora to [[Choquequirao]] trek **80 kilometers (50 mi) 5- to 6-day trek on Ausangate Circuit *[[Colca Canyon]] near [[Arequipa]] **60 kilometers (37 mi) 5-day trek around Canyon or other single-day and multi-day hikes

[[File:Cono de Arita, Salar de Arizaro (Argentina).jpg|thumb|[[Salar de Arizaro|Cono de Arita]], a natural monument in [[Argentina]].]] [[File:Wik Dąb Bogusława, Puszcza Wkrzańska SDC17003.JPG|thumb|[[Bogusław Oak]], a natural monument in the [[Poland|Polish]]
forest named [[Puszcza Wkrzańska]] near [[Leśno Górne]].]] A '''natural monument''' is a natural or natural/cultural feature of outstanding or unique value because of its inherent rarity, representative of aesthetic qualities or cultural significance.
Under [[World Commission on Protected Areas]] guidelines, natural monuments are level III, described as: :"Areas are set aside to protect a specific natural monument, which can be a landform, sea mount, submarine cavern, geological feature such as a cave or even a living feature such as an ancient grove. They are generally quite small protected areas and often have high visitor value." This is a lower level of protection than level II (national parks) and level I (wilderness areas).
The European Environment Agency's guidelines for selection of a natural monument are:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://glossary.eea.europa.eu/EEAGlossary/N/natural_monument|title=Environmental Terminology Discovery Service — EEA|publisher=glossary.eea.europa.eu|access-date=2006-06-22|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060718151533/http://glossary.eea.europa.eu/EEAGlossary/N/natural_monument|archive-date=2006-07-18|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> * The area should contain one or more features of outstanding significance. Appropriate natural features include waterfalls, caves, [[impact crater|crater]]s, fossil beds, sand dunes and marine features, along with unique or representative [[fauna]] and [[flora]]; associated cultural features might include cave dwellings, cliff-top forts, archaeological sites, or natural sites which have heritage significance to indigenous peoples. * The area should be large enough to protect the integrity of the feature and its immediately related surroundings.
<gallery widths="154px" heights="200px" perrow="5" caption="Natural monument signs selection"> File:Naturdenkmal Glienicke.jpg|Natural monument sign in [[Heiligengrabe]]-Glienicke File:Icono monumento natural.png|Natural monument sign in [[Gran Canaria]] </gallery>
==See also== *[[IUCN Protected Area Management Categories|IUCN Protected Area Management Categories: Category III Natural Monument or Feature]] *[[U.S. National Monument]] *[[World Conservation Union]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{commons category|Natural monuments}} *[http://www.biodiversitya-z.org/areas/38/ A-Z of Areas of Biodiversity Importance: Natural Monument or Feature] *[http://uc.socioambiental.org/en/prote%C3%A7%C3%A3o-integral/natural-monument Natural Monuments in Brazil]
{{Authority control}} [[Category:Natural monuments| ]] [[Category:Outdoor sculptures]] [[Category:Open-air museums]] [[Category:Monument types]] [[Category:Protected areas]]
{{geo-term-stub}}

The '''shower-curtain effect''' in [[physics]] describes the phenomenon of how a [[shower curtain]] gets blown inward with a running shower. The problem of identifying the cause of this effect has been featured in [[Scientific American]] magazine, with several theories given to explain the phenomenon but no definite conclusion.
The shower-curtain effect may also be used to describe the observation how nearby phase front distortions of an optical wave are more severe than remote distortions of the same amplitude.
==Hypotheses ==
===Buoyancy hypothesis === Also called Chimney effect or [[Stack effect]], observes that warm air (from the hot shower) rises out over the shower curtain as cooler air (near the floor) pushes in under the curtain to replace the rising air. By pushing the curtain in towards the shower, the (short range) vortex and [[Coandă effect]]s become more significant. However, the shower-curtain effect persists when cold water is used, implying that this cannot be the only mechanism at work.<ref name=straight>{{cite web|url=http://www.straightdope.com/columns/read/1369/why-does-the-shower-curtain-blow-in-despite-the-water-pushing-it-out-revisited|title=The Straight Dope: Why does the shower curtain blow in despite the water pushing it out (revisited)?|website=www.straightdope.com}}</ref>
See also [[Cooling tower]].
===Bernoulli effect hypothesis === The most popular explanation given for the shower-curtain effect is [[Bernoulli's principle]].<ref name=straight/> Bernoulli's principle states that an increase in velocity results in a decrease in pressure. This theory presumes that the water flowing out of a [[shower head]] causes the air through which the water moves to start flowing in the same direction as the water. This movement would be parallel to the plane of the shower curtain. If air is moving across the inside surface of the shower curtain, Bernoulli's principle says the air pressure there will drop. This would result in a pressure differential between the inside and outside, causing the curtain to move inward. It would be strongest when the gap between the bather and the curtain is smallest - resulting in the curtain attaching to the bather.{{Citation needed|date=January 2012}}
===Horizontal vortex hypothesis === A computer simulation of a typical bathroom found that none of the above theories pan out in their analysis, but instead found that the spray from the shower-head drives a horizontal [[vortex]]. This vortex has a low-pressure zone in the centre, which sucks the curtain.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://zidbits.com/2010/11/the-shower-curtain-effect/|title=What Is The Shower Curtain Effect?| date=2010-11-17| accessdate=2011-06-29}}</ref><ref name=straight/>
David Schmidt of University of Massachusetts was awarded the 2001 [[Ig Nobel Prize]] in Physics for his partial solution to the question of why shower curtains billow inwards. He used a [[computational fluid dynamics]] code to achieve the results. Professor Schmidt is adamant that this was done "for fun" in his own free time without the use of grants.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/science/discoveries/news/2001/10/47334|title=Shower Curtain Rises on Ig Nobels|publisher=}}</ref>
===The Coandă effect=== The [[Coandă effect]], also known as "boundary layer attachment", is the tendency of a moving fluid to adhere to an adjacent wall.<ref name=straight/>
===Condensation=== A hot shower will produce steam that condenses on the shower side of the curtain; lowering the pressure there. In a steady state the steam will be replaced by new steam delivered by the shower but in reality the water temperature will fluctuate and lead to times when the net steam production is negative.{{Citation needed|date=January 2012}}
===Air pressure=== Colder dense air outside and hot less dense air inside causes higher air pressure on the outside to force the shower curtain inwards to equalise the air pressure, this can be observed simply when the bathroom door is open allowing cold air into the bathroom.
==Solutions== Many shower curtains come with features to reduce the shower-curtain effect. They may have adhesive suction cups on the bottom edges of the curtain, which are then pushed onto the sides of the shower when in use. Others may have magnets at the bottom, though these are not effective on acrylic or fiberglass tubs.
It's possible to use a telescopic shower curtain rod to block the curtain on it's lower part and to prevent it from sucking inside.
Hanging the curtain rod higher or lower, or especially further away from the shower head, can reduce the effect. A (convex) curved shower rod can also be used to hold the curtain against the inside wall of a tub.
A weight can be attached to a long string and the string attached to the curtain rod in the middle of the curtain (on the inside). Hanging the weight low against the curtain just above the rim of the shower pan or tub makes it an effective billowing deterrent without allowing the weight to hit the pan or tub and damage it.
There are a few alternative solutions that either attach to the shower curtain directly, attach to the shower rod or attach to the wall.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.sciam.com/article.cfm?id=why-does-the-shower-curta Scientific American: Why does the shower curtain move toward the water?] * [http://www.straightdope.com/classics/a2_104.html Why does the shower curtain blow up and in instead of down and out?] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-Ffa5zHBPFQ Video demonstration of how this phenomenon could be solved.] * [http://www.straightdope.com/columns/010810.html The Straight Dope: Why does the shower curtain blow in despite the water pushing it out (revisited)?] * [http://improbable.com/ig/ig-pastwinners.html 2001 Ig Nobel Prize Winners] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060207093353/http://www.fluent.com/about/news/newsletters/01v10i2/a8.htm Fluent NEWS: Shower Curtain Grabs Scientist – But He Lives to Tell Why] * [https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=6430581 Arggh, Why Does the Shower Curtain Attack Me? by Joe Palca]. ''[[All Things Considered]]'', [[National Public Radio]]. November 4, 2006. (audio) * [http://www.opticsinfobase.org/ao/abstract.cfm?id=43553 Experimental Investigation of the Influence of the Relative Position of the Scattering Layer on Image Quality: the Shower Curtain Effect] * [http://sci.esa.int/science-e/www/object/index.cfm?fobjectid=31415&fbodylongid=862 The shower curtain effect; ESA ]
